==History of Modernism==
  +   +
[[Image:SAKhan.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Syed Ahmed Khan]]]]
  +
{{Copyedit|date=December 2008}}
  +
In the late nineteenth century, [[Mohammed Abduh]] and [[Rashid Rida]] undertook to defend and modernize Islam to match Western institutions and social processes. This project sought to superimpose the world of the nineteenth century on the extensive body of Islamic knowledge that had accumulated in a different context.{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Although these efforts had little impact at first, they gained momentum with the demise of the Ottoman Caliphate in 1924 and promotion of secular liberalism â particularly with a new breed of writers being pushed to the fore, including Egyptian [[Ali Abdel Raziq|Ali Abd al-Raziq]]'s publication "Islam and the Foundations of Governance", which advocated the separation of Islam and the state. Subsequent secular writers including [[Farag Foda]], [[al-Ashmawi]], [[Muhamed Khalafallah]], [[Taha Husayn]] and [[Husayn Amin]] have advanced similar arguments.{{Fact|date=August 2008}}
  +   +
==Theology==
  +   +
{{POV-section|date=December 2008}}
  +
{{OR-section|date=April 2009}}
  +   +
The modernist movement of the nineteenth century attempted to reconcile Islamic thought with Western social processes, philosophies and institutions. This led to an emphasis on [[utilitarian]] principles and selective scriptural readings rather than a coherent and detailed [[methodology]].{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Considerable critique against this approach includes allegations of politicisation and manipulation of [[fiqh|jurisprudence]] for secular ends.{{Fact|date=August 2008}}
  +   +
Modernists are said to use three approaches in their advocacy of a revised body of jurisprudence:
  +   +
* Restricting traditional Islamic law by limiting its basis to the [[Quran]] and authentic [[Sunnah]], limiting the Sunna with radical [[Hadith]] criticism.<ref>Muhammad 'Abduh, for example, said a Muslim was obliged to accept only mutawatir hadith, and was free to reject others about which he had doubts - Risalat al-Tawhid, 17th Printing, Cairo: Maktabat al-Qahira, 1379/1960, pp. 201-3; English translation by K. Cragg and I. Masa'ad, The Theology of Unity London: Allen and Unwin, 1966, pp. 155-56. Ahmad Amin, in his popular series on Islamic cultural history, cautiously suggested that there were few if any mutawatir hadith (especially, Fajr al-Islam, 10th edition Cairo: Maktabat al-Nahda al-Misriyya, 1965, p. 218; see also G. H. A. Juynboll, The Authenticity of the Tradition Literature: Discussions in Modern Egypt (Leiden: Brill, 1969), and my Faith of a Modern Muslim Intellectual, p. 113.</ref> A few, such as [[Ghulam Ahmed Pervez]] in Pakistan, go further and treat only the Quran as absolutely binding.
  +   +
* A more or less radical (re)interpretation of the authoritative sources. This is particularly the case with the Quranic texts on [[polygyny]], the [[hadd]] (penal) punishments, [[jihad]], and treatment of unbelievers, which conflict with "modern" views.<ref> See Quran 4:3 on polygyny, 5:38 on cutting off the hand of the thief, 24:2-5 on whipping for fornication (the provision for stoning for adultery is in the Hadith). On jihad and the treatment of unbelievers, the difficult passages for modernists are the so-called "verses of the sword," such as 9:5 on the Arab pagans and 9:29 on the people of the Book â Shepard, W E, op cit, 1987, p. 330</ref> In some cases modernist (re)interpretation can find support in the text, such as the requirement of four witnesses to adultery, which may have the effect of voiding the hadd in practice, or the permission of four wives conditioned on the ability of the husband to treat them fairly, which is argued as denied by another passage.{{Fact|date=August 2008}}
  +   +
* An [[apologetic]] which links aspects of the Islamic tradition with Western ideas and practices, and claims Western practices in question were originally derived from Islam.<ref>Ibid., pp. 312-13</ref> Modernist apologetic has however been severely criticized by many scholars as superficial, tendentious and even psychologically destructive, so much so that the term "apologetics" has almost become a term of abuse in the literature on modern Islam.<ref>Smith's criticism of Farid Wajdi in Islam in âModern Historyâ, pp. 139-59, and Gibb's complaint about "the intellectual confusions and the paralyzing romanticism which cloud the minds of the modernists of today" - âModern Trends in Islamâ, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1947, pp. 105-6.</ref>
  +   +
===History===
  +
In relation to the [[Islamic Caliphate]], some Modernists argue there was no glorious history as the first three [[Caliphs]] were assassinated. Furthermore, Spain, Africa and Persia were autonomous at different points in history resulting in there being no one [[Caliphate]] state, contradicting traditional historiography which relates the [[Umayyad]], [[Abbasid]] and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Caliphates as maintaining general political and territorial integrity with fragmentation and divisions being the exception.{{Fact|date=December 2008}}
  +   +
===Politics===
  +
Modernists believe Islam is not an ideology but a faith and has no specific prescriptions for modes of governance, as a plethora of approaches to government have been used throughout Muslim history.{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Unlike Christianity, they argue Muslim history has not battled for the separation of church and state since clerics were almost always a separate entity from the rulers.{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Many Modernists advocate Western secular politics, namely, Democracy.
